subject: Re: [junit] @Ignore with a time
msgSnippet: I think ignore seems way better than someone just commenting a test out (something I guess we have all seen happen or, god forbid,  even done ourselves
messageBody:
I think ignore seems way better than someone just commenting a test out
(something I guess we have all seen happen or, god forbid, even done
ourselves sometime in the past).
I think that your timebomb concept seems way better than ignore for the
reason that you will HAVE to deal with it eventually I'd like that option if
I ever use ignore since I KNOW that I will forget to change one or two of
them :).

About situation 1 Iguess it is a result of system-testing I don't think
using some other tool than jUnit would change the fact that you do have a
datadependency in your system-tets that you don't own. I agree lets not have
the "don't system test with jUnit discussion". To me it seems that it would
be great if you could find a way to replicate enough of the data you don't
own to be able to run your tests but I bet you wanted that like a million
times yourself and since you've been living with that for 3 years I bet
mocking it out is not an option either, tough one :S

About situation 2 I have been in the situation myself many times and
although I always feel I missed some baby-step I should have taken or that I
should have checked something in before I started on this big thingy... I
guess checing in with ignore is better than not checking in as long as you
don't ruin someone elses day... One concern I have is that you say that you
write seeral tests and they are failing why not one at the time, is it like
a TODO list? is that why you feel safe to check them in?

/Joakim







On 6/8/06, Brett L. Schuchert <schuchert@...> wrote:
>
> We use JUnit for both unit tests and some level of integration tests. We
> can have a side discussion on the merits of that, but it's a fact. We have
> right now around 60 developers working across 10 projects. All 10 projects
> share a common architecture and supporting components. I'd guess we have
> around 7000 unit tests across the 10 projects. Our coverage is a bit lacking
> but I know it's helped.
>
> Here are 2 situations where we'd use this:
>
>
> Situation 1:
> Some of our tests acquire information from external systems we do not have
> control over. Those systems sometimes go through maintenance for a day or
> two or sometimes those systems clear out all of the test data and repopulate
> (I hate that we cannot own a part of the test data, but it's been a
> political issue for 3 years). When this happens, we need to update tests. It
> usually takes a 1 to 3 days to do that - often the information the test uses
> is externalized, we still have to find appropriate replacement keys. So we
> don't actually update the test, we update the data driven part of the tests.
> While that happens, other development would lose out on CI or we'd have to
> disable those tests. It'd be nice to just put a 3-day delay on them. Then
> they'd start running again automatically. So I guess the ignore is until a
> date and after that the test continues to run.
>
> Situation 2:
> I'm working on something in the trunk. I want to write tests and check in
> my work. I could work in a branch, check in all I want and then make sure to
> merge that branch back into the trunk. However, if I do that, I have to keep
> the branch up to date with the trunk and vice versa - merging in both
> directions. This is a pain. So I'd rather just write several tests. Put on
> the ignore, check them in. Then take out the ignore while I continue my
> development (better yet, maybe I could set some environment variable when
> executing tests to ignore the ignore!-).
>
> We have a utility class called TimeBomb (we're still using JUnit 3.8.1).
> When we want to disable a test, we put a time bomb in the test. That test
> will eventually start to ACTIVELY fail in the near future. Here's an example
> from something else I'm working on, on the side:
> http://schuchert.wikispaces.com/JUnit+4.x#TimeBomb
>
> Brett
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...<joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>
> >
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Thursday, June 8, 2006 6:09:54 AM
> Subject: Re: [junit] @Ignore with a time
>
> I think that would address my concern that @ignore can be forgotten.
> A failing test would be a really nice reminder: "ignore expired: <your
> message>"
> I have not yet used ignore I have not seen the need, when do you typically
> need it?
>
> On 6/8/06, Brett L. Schuchert <schuchert@yahoo. com> wrote:
> >
> > I've been working with a group for the past 3.5 years and we've been
> > using JUnit from the beginning. A while back, as the project grew,
> > there were times when we would break tests (or because we had
> > external dependencies that we had to wait and had not yet mocked
> > things out), tests would fail for a few days before we could get to
> > them.
> >
> > This stopped our CI, so we introduced a helper class, TimeBomb. We'd
> > add a call to TimeBomb with a date and the test would stop failing
> > until after the provided date.
> >
> > It was an active way to remind us go back and fix something in a few
> > days.
> >
> > @Ignore has a message. What about adding a date? Ignore until the
> > date, after which the test will fail by throwing a runtime exception?
> >
> > Is that crazy?
> >
> > Brett
> >
> >
